posts.name: James Racadio
posts.cooked: My team is planning on using a gyro this year as well as Falcon 500 motors (which it is our understanding that they have built in encoders. Is that true?). I know how they both work and what they provide us, but my question is how can they help us get  more precise autonomous movements? For example: Is there a way in Labview to tell a motor to run until it reaches a certain angle and then stop? Is there a way to use the encoders to tell a motor to turn so many times and then stop? How can I use those sensors to plan out a path during auto? Last year, we used flat sequences for auto and it worked well, but this year we are trying to do better and possibly pick up another cone. I am a researcher, so links to articles, tutorials, videos, etc are much appreciated. I have searched but haven’t found anything helpful.

posts.name: Jim simpson
posts.cooked:
Yes.

You can use encoders on the drive wheels, along with position control to drive a particular distance forwards or backwards.   1) remember the current encoder distances.   2) add the distance you want to go.  This becomes the setpoint.  (This is only done before starting to move.)  3) Every cycle calculate the error — Setpoint distance - current encoder distance.  4) Use this error with position control to set the motor output.

The same thing can be done to spin the robot a particular number of degrees.   1) remember the current gyro position. 2) Calculate the setpoint by adding the number of degrees to turn to the remembered setpoint (This is only done before starting to move.)  3) Every cycle calculate the error — Setpoint gyro angle - current gyro angle.  4) Use this error with position control to set the motor output.  In this case one of the motors will be -1 times the other.

This book has details on how position control works. GitHub - jsimpso81/FRC_Secret_Book_Of_FRC_LabVIEW_2: Secret book of FRC LabVIEW version 2.x The output of position control can be either wheel speed demand or motor output.    Position control works well as long as the output is zero when the target distance or gyro angle has been reached.

link_counts.title: GitHub - jsimpso81/FRC_Secret_Book_Of_FRC_LabVIEW_2: Secret book of FRC LabVIEW version 2.x

posts.name: Jim simpson
posts.cooked:
I was thinking that perhaps I should add a little bit extra on some suggestions on architecting these routines.   There are different ways to do this but this is what I’d generally suggest:

Create a generic position control VI.  Inputs could be: Error,  Max output, Min output, Error threshold, Error deadband, Desired on target count.   Outputs could be: Control output, On target.   (Generally we have found that setting “on target” works best if the error is within the deadband for X consecutive calls where X is the input parameter “on target count”.

Create a generic position control VI.  Inputs could be: Error,  Max output, Min output, Error threshold, Error deadband, Desired on target count.   Outputs could be: Control output, On target.   (Generally we have found that setting “on target” works best if the error is within the deadband for X consecutive calls where X is the input parameter “on target count”.

Create immediate execution routines for the different actions you want.  For example for driving forward, inputs would be:  Distance to move, Left and Right encoder distances (scaled useful units), initialize.  Outputs would be control output, on target.   Things defined internally would be position control tuning parameters, desired on target count.    This routine can directly be called in teleop inside a case structure triggered by pressing and holding a button.  Use an On-Edge detection (outside the case statement) to set the Initialize input.

Create immediate execution routines for the different actions you want.  For example for driving forward, inputs would be:  Distance to move, Left and Right encoder distances (scaled useful units), initialize.  Outputs would be control output, on target.   Things defined internally would be position control tuning parameters, desired on target count.    This routine can directly be called in teleop inside a case structure triggered by pressing and holding a button.  Use an On-Edge detection (outside the case statement) to set the Initialize input.

For auto create a wrapper for 2 execution routine above.  This wrapper would include a 20 millisecond loop that would call the execution routine.  The loop would terminate when the move is complete.   We often add a timer to terminate the loop even if the action doesn’t complete when the timer expires.

For auto create a wrapper for 2 execution routine above.  This wrapper would include a 20 millisecond loop that would call the execution routine.  The loop would terminate when the move is complete.   We often add a timer to terminate the loop even if the action doesn’t complete when the timer expires.

Often the encoder values and motor control demands are put into global variables wrapped with setter / getter VIs.  This allows the encoder reads and motor outputs to put in one and only one place – periodic tasks.

Often the encoder values and motor control demands are put into global variables wrapped with setter / getter VIs.  This allows the encoder reads and motor outputs to put in one and only one place – periodic tasks.

(This is a lot easier than it sounds.)    There are other ways to do this…

posts.name: mshafer1
posts.cooked:
Here’s some more tutorials around writing autonomous code and using sensors:

FRC LabVIEW Tutorials and examples

FRC LabVIEW Tutorials and examples - Utilizing the producer-consumer architecture to code autonomous without re-writing actuator code.

FRC LabVIEW Tutorials and examples - A methodology for storing Autonomous configuration in the Autonomous.vi Front Panel to allow for multiple runs with tweaks without re-deploying code.

reading a gyroscope https://www.team358.org/files/programming/ControlSystem2015-2019/labview/index.php#Gyroscope

Some basic example, including a dashboard read for which sequence to run https://www.team358.org/files/programming/ControlSystem2015-2019/labview/index.php#Autonomous

Using an encoder to drive a specific distance https://www.team358.org/files/programming/ControlSystem2015-2019/labview/index.php#Encoder
